questions.text: What is the mechanism of resistance by lactamases to Beta-lactam antibiotics?
questions.explanation:
ß-lactam antibiotics

MOA

ß-lactam antibiotics inhibit the last step in peptidoglycan synthesis by acylating the transpeptidase via cleavage of the -CO-N-bond of the ß-lactam ring, thus inhibiting cell wall synthesis

Drug groups

1. Penicillin

2. Cephalosporin

3. Carbapenems

4. Monobactam (Aztreonam)

Resistance

It occurs through one of the four mechanisms:

  1. Modification of target PBPs (Option A)
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Impaired penetration of drugs to target PBPs
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Antibiotic efflux (Option C)
  4. ﻿﻿﻿Inactivation of antibiotic by lactamases (Option B)

ß-lactamases are enzymes produced by certain bacteria that inactivate ß-lactam antibiotics by hydrolysis of the ß-lactam ring in their structure.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs should not be consumed by a patient with bacterial vaginosis and trichomoniasis currently on metronidazole?
questions.explanation:
Metronidazole

MOA
  • Prodrug is converted to active form through nitro group reduction inside the bacteria → formation of nitric oxide free radicals → causes DNA damage → inhibits replication.
  • Inhibits PFOR enzyme (pyruvate ferritin oxido reductase) in protozoa → DNA damage.

Uses

  • Giardiasis (in HIV-positive patients)
  • Entamoeba histolytica → Amebic dysentery & amebic liver abscess
  • Trichomonas vaginalis
  • Bacterial Vaginosis
  • Dracunculus (guinea worm)
  • Gardenella / bacterial vaginosis
  • Empiric intra-abdominal and soft tissue anaerobic infections
  • H. pylori gastritis (combined with proton pump inhibitor)
  • Prophylaxis for colorectal surgery
  • Fulminant C.difficile infection (IV metronidazole + oral vancomycin)
  • Mild to moderate Crohn's disease

Adverse effects
  • Metallic taste, intensely bitter
  • Headache, nausea, dry mouth (most common)
  • Vomiting, diarrhoea, and abdominal distress
  • Dysuria, cystitis, and a sense of pelvic pressure
  • Dizziness, vertigo,
  • Neurotoxicity: Peripheral neuropathy, numbness, paresthesias, ataxia
  • Brown color urine
  • Urticaria, flushing, and pruritus ( rare cause of Stevens-Johnson syndrome)

Drug Interaction
  • Inhibitor of CYP enzymes
  • Disulfiram-like effect: abdominal distress, vomiting, flushing, headache or psychosis with alcoholic beverages during or within 3 days of therapy.
  • Precipitate lithium toxicity
  • Prothrombin time prolongation with warfarin (anticoagulant).

Contraindications
  • CNS diseases
  • Severe hepatic disease
  • First trimester of pregnancy

What is the clinical application of tafenoquine among the options provided?

options.label: D
options.text: Treatment of malaria in children <2 years

questions.correct_answer: A. Radical cure of Plasmodium vivax
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A.

Clinical Use

Description

Radical cure of Plasmodium vivax

Tafenoquine is used for the radical cure of Plasmodium vivax malaria. It is administered in combination with a blood schizonticide to treat the acute infection and to prevent relapse by eliminating the dormant liver stages (hypnozoites) of the parasite.

Prophylaxis of malaria in pregnancy

Tafenoquine may be used for the prophylaxis of malaria in pregnant women, particularly in areas where Plasmodium vivax is prevalent. However, its use in pregnancy requires careful consideration and should be determined by a healthcare professional based on the individual's risk-benefit profile.

Treatment of severe falciparum malaria

Tafenoquine is not typically used as a first-line treatment for severe falciparum malaria. Other antimalarial medications, such as artesunate or quinine, are commonly used in combination with other drugs for the treatment of severe malaria.

Treatment of malaria in children <2 years

Tafenoquine is not approved for use in children under the age of 18 years, including children younger than 2 years. Its safety and efficacy in pediatric populations have not been well established.

questions.explanation:
Integrase inhibitors

MOA
  • Prevent the formation of covalent bonds between host and viral DNA
  • Inhibit the process known as strand transfer, which is a critical step in the integration of viral DNA into the host genome.

Drugs

Ends with the word -gravir: BCDER

  • Bictegravir
  • Cabotegravir
  • Dolutegravir (most used in India and safe during pregnancy)
  • Elvitegravir (used in combination with cobicistat)
  • Raltegravir

Route
  • All oral drugs except Cabotegravir (IM, once every 3 months)

Metabolism
  • CYP3A4 substrates
  • Rifampicin reduces the effect, hence increasing the dose of the integrase inhibitor

Uses
  • Treatment and post-exposure prophylaxis of HIV
  • Dolutegravir and Lamivudine: First line in treatment-naive HIV patients

Side effects
  • Rashes
  • Steven Johnson syndrome: Epidermis of the skin is damaged
  • Raltegravir: Rhabdomyolysis, DRESS
  • Bictegravir: Increase metformin concentration, hepatoxicity
  • Avoid administration with divalent cations (magnesium- or aluminium-containing antacids, iron supplements)

Type of antivirals

Mechanism of action

Examples

Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors (RTIs)

Inhibit reverse transcriptase, the enzyme that converts viral RNA into DNA

Zidovudine, Lamivudine, Tenofovir, Abacavir

Non-Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors (RTIs)

They bind directly to reverse transcriptase, blocking its ability to transcribe viral RNA into DNA.

Efavirenz, Nevirapine, Etravirine

Protease Inhibitors

Inhibit viral protease, preventing the maturation of viral proteins and the assembly of new virions.

Ritonavir, Lopinavir, Atazanavir

Integrase Inhibitors

Inhibit the integrase enzyme, preventing the integration of viral DNA into the host cell's genome.

Raltegravir, Dolutegravir, Elvitegravir

Fusion Inhibitors

Prevent the fusion of the viral envelope with the host cell membrane.

Enfuvirtide (Fuzeon), Maraviroc

Neuraminidase Inhibitors

Inhibit neuraminidase, an enzyme needed for the release of new virions from infected cells.

Oseltamivir (Tamiflu), Zanamivir

questions.text: Which of the following antibiotics acts by inhibiting the 50s ribosome?
questions.explanation:
Linezolid

Aspect

Description

Mechanism of Action
  • It inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 23S ribosomal RNA of the 50S ribosomal subunit.
  • It interferes with the formation of the ternary N-formylmethionyl-tRNA (tRNAf-Met)-70S initiation complex, preventing the initiation of protein synthesis.

Spectrum of Activity
  • Gram-positive cocci (aerobic and anaerobic): MRSA, VRSA, VRE, Strep. viridans, Strep. pneumoniae
  • Other sensitive bacteria: Clostridia, B. fragilis, M. tuberculosis.

Common Uses
  • Uncomplicated and complicated skin and soft tissue infections Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAPs)
  • Bacteremia.

Side Effects
  • Mild abdominal pain, nausea and diarrhoea.
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Optic neuritis
  • Bone marrow suppression (monitor platelet count)
  • Caution is advised when used concurrently with MAO inhibitors due to the risk of serotonin syndrome.

Causative agent

Transmission 

Chiggers (larval mites)

Vector 

Trombiculid mite (Leptotrombidium)

Geographical distribution 

Endemic in the “tsutsugamushi triangle” (parts of Asia, Australia, Pacific Islands).

Clinical manifestations

Fever, headache, muscle pain, eschar (dark, scab-like lesion at the site of bite), and lymphadenopathy.

Serological tests (ELISA, immunofluorescence) and molecular methods (PCR).

Avoid mite-infested areas, wearing protective clothing, and using insect repellants.

Complications 

Organ failure, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), neurological complications.
